title: Ed Woodward reveals what Man Utd are targeting in new signings
text:
The United chief wants players with both X factor and humbleness (Picture: Getty)

Manchester United executive vice-chairman Ed Woodward has outlined his vision for the club and says any future signings need to measure up off the pitch as much as on it.

The Red Devils altered their transfer strategy in the summer, moving away from the big-name players that had consistently backfired, such as Angel Di Maria, Bastian Schweinsteiger and Radamel Falcao.

Instead, manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer targeted young, hungry, British players, signing Daniel James from Swansea, Aaron Wan-Bissaka from Crystal Palace and Harry Maguire from Leicester City.

Daniel James’ arrival signified a clear shift in United’s transfer approach (Picture: Getty)

The onus has been on finding players with the United ‘DNA’ and Woodward has explained that performances on the pitch are not the only yardstick by which the club will decide targets.

Speaking about the club’s philosophy, Woodward told United We Stand: ‘Winning; playing attacking football with players that have an X factor; and giving youth a chance.

‘Added to that, we want players to come in who respect their teammates, the club, the history.

‘They must understand they are creating a legacy by coming to Manchester United. Nobody is bigger than the club. There should be both a humbleness and an arrogance.

‘Ole has brought a lot of the discipline back. Whatever manager we have has to buy into that philosophy and Ole is a walking, talking version of that.

Solskjaer will be given time to make his mark at Old Trafford (Picture: PA)

‘Let’s play this out with Ole in terms of the cultural reboot.

‘It [appointing Solskjaer permanently] wasn’t pivotal to it [finishing top four] one way or another. I want to take a long-term view — Ole was hired with the long-term view that he will be successful.’
